==Japanese==
<div style="float:right;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}}
{{wikipedia|Dolphin}}
[[File:Comdolph.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|海豚}} (''iruka''): a '''[[dolphin]]''' or '''[[porpoise]]'''.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|sort=いるか}}

===Etymology===
Unclear. One of the more likely native-Japanese theories is that this was originally a compound of {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=いるか}} elements {{compound|lang=ja|sort=いるか|魚|tr1=iwo|t1=fish|食|tr2=uka|t2=food, something used as food}}.

{{IPAchar|/iwo uka/}} → {{IPAchar|/iru uka/}} → {{IPAchar|/iruka/}}

Another possibility is that it was a borrowing from {{etyl|ain|ja|sort=いるか}}. Compare Sakhalin Ainu {{m|ain|リク|tr=riku}}, {{m|ain|イリク|tr=iriku}}, or Kuril Ainu {{m|ain|リカ|tr=rika||whale}}.<ref>'''2005''', Martine Robbeets (2005:190) ''Is Japanese Related to Korean, Tungusic, Mongolic and Turkic?''</ref>

Given the unlikely sound shift required for the {{etyl|ojp|-}} derivation, an origin from {{etyl|ain|-}} seems more likely.

The {{lang|ja|海豚}} spelling, which literally means “sea pig”, is borrowed from {{etyl|zh|ja|sort=いるか}}.
